msgSnippet: ... But that is precisely what I said.  The bad advice was the _categorical_ statement that comments are waste. Comments which just restate what the code says
messageBody:
On Tue, 23 Sep 2003, Ilja Preuss wrote:

> > Telling people that code should not be commented, that
> > comments are waste, remains extremely bad advice.
>
> This is true if you were only saying that.

But that is precisely what I said. The bad advice was the
_categorical_ statement that comments are waste.

Comments which just restate what the code says might be considered
waste, and there is of course a tendency for comments to lag the code:
people often change the code without changing the accompanying
comments.

On the other hand, if the code embodies application-specific knowledge,
it is usually important and often essential to explain.

I had a friend who worked for a large manufacturer of sausages. He
was an OR expert. His code saved the manufacturer several million
dollars a year by minimizing the use of ingredients.

They had a corporate reorganization. His Sausage program was turned
over to the DP department because, after all, it was software. The
DP guys couldn't figure out what it did. So they optimized it away.

Walter was well known for his incredibly precise, tight code. It
was beautiful.

He was also very economical with comments. That wasn't so wonderful
for those who had to decrypt the code when he wasn't there.

> Saying "write your code in a way that it doesn't need comments" is very
> good advice, on the other hand.

That I would agree with. Although some of us do like Javadocs.

> And in my experience you *can* learn to
> write code in a way that you very seldom need to fall back on this
> crutch.

Crutch? Name-calling helps no one.

Can we return to JUnit and the thrill of unit testing?
